_header: I love a flower of sweet odor
Note: Variant forms of burden written after stanzas 4, 6.
_description: The Tudor Rose — six 5-line stanzas (aaabb) and a five-line burden: ‘I loue I loue and wom loue ye / I loue a floure of fressh beaute / I loue another as well as ye / Than shal beprovid here anon / Yff we iii can agre in on’, with music by Sir Thomas Phelipps

BLAdd5465.First Lines:
I loue a flour of swete odourMagerome gentyll or
                    lavendour…
BLAdd5465.Last Lines: …Joyed may we beOure prince to se and rosys thre
